awd_titl_txt: DCL: NSF INCLUDES EAGER: A Study of Online Scientific and Scholarly Communities for Broadening Participation in STEM
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is conducting exploratory research about two currently existing online scientific and scholarly communities (OSSCs), each of which was established to broaden participation in STEM in identified target communities: (a) the NSF INCLUDES Open Forum (NSF-1748345); and (b) the Deaf STEM Community Alliance's Deaf and Hard of Hearing Virtual Academic Community (NSF-1127955). The goals of the proposed study are: 1) to apply the information systems theory of the life cycle of online communities and the theory of social capital to understand the dynamics of two NSF-sponsored OSSCs that are focused on broadening participation in STEM; and 2) to strengthen NSF INCLUDES Network activities with best practices and lessons learned from the project. The project is conducting comparative analyses of the OSSCs: 1) to determine life-cycle stages of the OSSCs; 2) to examine leadership and engagement activities of community engagement managers in each community and how they evolve over time; and 3) to explore the perceptions of community members. 

This exploratory research project was proposed in response to the NSF INCLUDES Dear Colleague Letter: Announcement of an Effort to Expand the NSF INCLUDES National Network (NSF 17-111).  The DCL states that Early-concept Grants for Exploratory Research (EAGER) proposals should produce findings and results that will generate new insights for the NSF INCLUDES National Network, suggest potential strategies for engaging NSF's existing broadening participation activities in the Network, and/or highlight lessons learned that could inform the NSF INCLUDES Launch Pilots and Alliances as they develop.  The NSF INCLUDES program focuses on catalyzing the STEM enterprise to collaboratively work for inclusive change.

It is anticipated that the research findings from this project will inform collaborative broadening participation efforts of online STEM communities to advance inclusive STEM education, research and workforce development.  Together with other NSF INCLUDES Network activities, this research is contributing to positive, transformative change within the U.S. STEM workforce and research community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Sociological research on scientific and scholarly communities finds that members of these groups tend to collaborate with others when face-to-face relationships superseded online associations. However, current financial and public health constraints have curtailed many opportunities for face-to-face meetings. Online communities offer to fill the void. This project compared the two platforms of the Deaf STEM Community Alliance’s Virtual Academic Community (DHHVAC), which were established using the Google+/Currents and Facebook private communities. The focal points included community growth, engagement and leadership, and perceived social capital. The original proposal included a comparison with the NSF INCLUDES Open Forum platform, but the project was unable to obtain data that would accommodate those comparisons.

 

Intellectual Merit—The goals of the project are to: 1) apply the information systems theory of the life cycle of online communities and the theory of social capital to understand the dynamics of NSF-sponsored online communities; and, 2) strengthen NSF INCLUDES Network activities with best practices and lessons learned from the project.

Broader Impacts: This project enhances understanding about current NSF INCLUDES broadening participation efforts that utilize online communities. It will create greater capacity for STEM fields by increasing understanding about how online communities can enhance scientific and scholarly relationships.

 

The project included three studies: 1) a life cycle study; 2) a study of the role of community engagement managers; and, 3) a study of the impact of social capital.

Life cycle study. The life cycle study employed user engagement data to determine the viability of the DHHVAC community on two platforms. The Google+/Currents platform, started in January 2012, was limited to comments and reactions to posts. Early on, the platform grew, but has since matured and is in its decline. The Facebook private community, initiated in October 2015 was vibrant until the 2021-22 year. It is unknown as to which factors are influencing user engagement, but factors such as design and public reputation are thought to exert pressure on member participation. Other sources noted that Facebook participation (overall) was lower during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Community engagement manager study. The community engagement manager (CEM) is a relatively new career path for online communities. CEMs help to recruit, train, and encourage member participation. The DHHVAC used two managers who used different strategies. The project’s principal investigator emphasized program development, while the primary CEM concentrated on interpersonal skills.

Social capital. A third segment of this project was to study the impact of social capital on the DHHVAC. A survey was conducted of active members of the Facebook group. Respondents answered an 18-question online survey about user engagement, group identity, trust, and perceived benefits of group membership. Respondents emphasized group identity and trust as central to their participation in the DHHVAC. They also enjoyed learning about new STEM innovations and meeting others who are DHH and interested in STEM. A literature search on social capital within the context of the DHH community yielded few studies, which suggests that additional work needs to be done to understand the role of social capital within the DHH community.
